params.text: In this activity, you will learn how to obtain the sum of the two roots (up to multiplicities) of a quadratic equation.

metadata.title: Sum of the Roots of a Quadratic Equation

feedback.title: Correct
feedback.subtitle: That is correct.  The sum of the roots of the quadratic equation is 5.

feedback.title: Incorrect answer.
feedback.subtitle: No, it is not -5.  Sorry.  Please proceed to read the notes that follow, then proceed from there to re-try this question.

feedback.title: Incorrect answer.
feedback.subtitle: No, the sum is not 6.  Please proceed to read the notes that follow, then proceed from there to re-try this question.

branchingQuestion.question: What is the sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(x^2-5x+6=0\).

params.text:
The sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) is \(-b/a\).

That is to say, if \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are the roots of this quadratic equation, then

\(r_1+r_2=-b/a\).

 

Example 1. What are the sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(x^2-5x+4\)?  The answer is \(5\), since for this quadratic equation \(a=1, b=-5\), and \(c=4\), so that \(-b/a=-(-5)/1=5/1=5\).  Thus, the sum of the two roots of this quadratic equation is \(5\).

Example 2. What are the sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(3x^2+5x+4\)?  The answer is \(-5/3\), since for this quadratic equation \(a=3, b=5\), and \(c=4\), so that \(-b/a=-5/3\).  Thus, the sum of the two roots of this quadratic equation is \(-5/3\).

metadata.title: Quadratic Equation: Sum of the Roots

params.text:
The sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) is \(-b/a\).

That is to say, if \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are the roots of this quadratic equation, then

\(r_1+r_2=-b/a\).

 

Example 1.  What are the sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(x^2-5x+4\)?  The answer is \(5\), since for this quadratic equation \(a=1, b=-5\), and \(c=4\), so that \(-b/a=-(-5)/1=5/1=5\).  Thus, the sum of the two roots of this quadratic equation is \(5\).

Example 2.  What are the sum of the roots of the quadratic equation \(3x^2+5x+4\)?  The answer is \(-5/3\), since for this quadratic equation \(a=3, b=5\), and \(c=4\), so that \(-b/a=-5/3\).  Thus, the sum of the two roots of this quadratic equation is \(-5/3\).
